triplets: Edible fruit produced by the apple tree (Malus domestica), commonly cultivated worldwide
Eating raw, cooking, baking, making juice, cider, sauces, and other culinary purposes
Fleshy fruit tissue, seeds, skin, and core
Seed that can grow into a new apple tree
Skin that protects the fruit and contains nutrients
Flesh (edible part) rich in water, fiber, vitamins, and sugars
Varieties range in color including red, green, yellow, or combinations of these colors depending on species and ripeness
Apple tree, orchard ecosystems, and fruit supply chains
Various farmers and horticulturists who cultivate apple trees commercially or domestically
Approximately 150–250 grams depending on variety and size
Typically 1–3 months after harvest under proper storage; the tree itself can live for decades producing fruit annually
